title-group.article-title: Design of an active hydromagnetic journal bearing

article-meta.aff: Machine Design Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Aeronautics, University of Patras, Greece

author-notes.corresp: CA Papadopoulos, Machine Design Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Aeronautics, University of Patras, Patras 26504, Greece. Email: chris.papadopoulos@upatras.gr

abstract.p: An active hydromagnetic journal bearing is designed and presented in this study, which is a new and innovative type of hybrid journal bearing. The proposed new mechatronic smart device has a common bearing shell that contains the two parts of the bearing, which is an attempt to combine the advantages of both types of bearings to overcome their drawbacks and give rise to new possibilities for instability control, increased load-carrying capacity, diagnostics of the rotor system, etc. The active hydromagnetic journal bearing should operate as either a hydrodynamic, active magnetic or hybrid journal bearing, depending on the needs of the rotating machinery. The hydrodynamic lubrication is developed in the inner bearing surface, and the electromagnets of the magnetic bearing are placed outside its outer surface. The active hydromagnetic journal bearing is designed with the appropriate clearance, so that both the hydrodynamic and magnetic bearings can operate. The suitable operational regions for the active hydromagnetic journal bearing are calculated and presented as a combination of the optimum ratio between the air gap and the clearance. Additionally, a simulation code using the two-dimensional finite element method (ANSYS) is developed to simulate the performance of the magnetic component of the active hydromagnetic journal bearing, and the ANSYS software is used to obtain a solution for the hydrodynamic pressure field. The dynamic characteristics of the hybrid journal bearing in terms of the stiffness and damping coefficients versus the Sommerfeld number are calculated and presented. In the hybrid bearing operation, the corresponding stiffness and damping coefficients are used to simulate the hydromagnetic bearing dynamic behaviour. Each hybrid coefficient consists of two parts; the hydrodynamic and the magnetic part. When the operation is purely hydrodynamic, the magnetic parts of the dynamic coefficients are zero and vice versa, whereas both parts are present in the hybrid operation mode.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hydrodynamic journal bearings, which are well-known machine elements, are widely used in rotor-bearing systems. Alternatively, during the past two decades, magnetic bearing technology has gained popularity, particularly for higher volume products. More and more complex bearing systems, such as air bearings or hydrostatic and hydrodynamic sliding bearings, are being replaced by active magnetic bearings (AMBs).1

Several passive magnetic bearing (PMB) configurations have been presented by Samanta and Hirani.2 The authors described in detail the techniques used by different inventors that have overcome the limitations of PMBs, such as low damping, low stiffness and their inherent instability. The authors also presented various hybridisation techniques used by other researchers to overcome the aforementioned problems.
PMBs have also been studied in terms of their instability behaviour by Bassani.3

As mentioned before, magnetic bearings are engineered systems whose use has been increasing in a wide range of applications. The following are the benefits of such a bearing system compared with hydrodynamic bearings: no mechanical contact between the bearing and the shaft, higher speed capabilities and the elimination of complex bearing lube oil systems. Numerous papers have been written on the broad subject of magnetic bearings. Many of these papers are concerned with applications of magnetic bearing technology with PMB, AMB and hybrid bearings (HBs) in regards to the permanent magnet. In the past decade, different design approaches have been used for the AMBs. These approaches relate to the controller design, sensing techniques and eddy current effects, and proposed solutions have been given for a variety of problems and their effects on the rotating systems stability in both industrial systems4–8 and biomedical applications.9
A full fault diagnosis for AMBs and rotor systems to monitor the closed-loop operation and to analyse fault patterns on-line in case any malfunction occurs has been proposed by Tsai et al.10

The design of a smart rotating machine involves the integration of controllable bearings, actuators and sensors to measure a defined set of physical variables, an on-line adaptive controller, a control algorithm to achieve the desired performance and an algorithm to re-configure the system in the event of faults. Burrows et al.11 discussed each of these issues and highlighted the progress that has been made. The key role played by AMBs in the evolution of smart or self-adaptive machine design is also described.

Allaire et al.12 considered the rotordynamics of a flexible rotor supported on AMBs and compared the process with a similar process for fluid film bearings (FFBs). The authors mention that vibration specification standards are good for industrial FFB-supported rotors; however, they are not adequate for AMB-supported rotors. In this article, the authors discuss comparative studies of rotors on AMBs and FFBs involving critical speeds, AMB and FFB stiffness and damping values, mode shapes and forced responses.

A new category of magnetic bearings is the hybrid system, which consists of a hydrodynamic bearing supported by a magnetic actuator or permanent magnets. In a number of articles,13–16 several configurations for the magnets and control system that focus on the vibration control of high-speed rotors have been presented. Computer simulations using the finite element method (FEM) have been used for the design for both hybrid systems17,18 and AMBs.19,20

As for the hydrodynamic journal bearings, their dynamics and stability depend on their stiffness and damping properties, and consequently, the structural integrity of the rotating system depends on these properties. Numerous articles have been written on the broad subject of bearing experimental and analytical properties calculations.21–23

Recently, El-Shafei and Dimitri24 presented a novel approach using a combination of an AMB and journal bearing to control the journal bearing instability. Farmakopoulos et al.25 presented the concept and the basic design of a new type of bearing, the active hydromagnetic journal bearing (AHJB); the authors also presented its dynamic characteristics.26

In this article, the new bearing design is analytically presented based on the exploitation of the advantages that each bearing type individually has. The new hydromagnetic bearing combines the high load-carrying capacity of the classical plain journal bearings and the high-rotational speeds allowed in AMBs.27 Using such a bearing, instabilities, such as oil whirl or oil whip, could be controlled, and consequences can be avoided. To this end, in high-speed applications, the hydrodynamic component does not operate, and the oil instability phenomenon does not occur. Additionally, the basic geometrical and operational characteristics and the optimum air gap-to-clearance ratios are investigated and presented. In addition, the stiffness and damping coefficients are calculated (a) for a hydrodynamic bearing; (b) for an AMB; and (c) for the newly proposed hydromagnetic bearing. The results are analytically presented and discussed. A computer code, which was developed in ANSYS using its multiphysics capability, is used to solve the Navier–Stokes equations for the hydrodynamic case and the electromagnetic Maxwell equations for the AMBs. Αn approach is also presented to combine the dynamic properties of the AMBs and FFBs.

This article is organised as follows: in the following section, the properties and performance characteristics of the hydrodynamic components are presented. Then, the relevant computational fluid dynamics (CFD) code introduced into ANSYS software is validated. Subsequently, the AMB characteristics are also presented, and the FEM solution code introduced into the same software, is also validated. Next, the hydromagnetic bearing is presented in terms of its geometry and, operation and its dynamic properties are also discussed. Finally, the major results are summarised and presented.

sec.title: Hydrodynamic journal bearing geometry
sec.p:
The geometry of a simple hydrodynamic bearing is shown in Figure 1, where Ob and Rb are the bearing centre and radius, respectively, Oj and Rj the journal centre and radius, respectively, e the shaft eccentricity, ϕ the attitude angle and L the bearing length. The relative eccentricity ratio ɛ is defined as ɛ=ec, where c is the radial clearance and h(θ, z) the film thickness. Figure 1.
Geometry of a typical hydrodynamic bearing.
According to classical hydrodynamic theory,28 the typical ratio of the rotor radius and radial clearance varies between 500 and 1000, so (1)500≤Rbc≤1000

To solve the Navier–Stokes equations, the flow is considered isothermal, and the minimum pressure value is assumed to be greater than the vapour pressure; thus, cavitation can be neglected, and our fluid is not an electrically conductive fluid. The mass conservation (2) and the momentum equation (3) for unsteady, incompressible and isothermal flow, with zero gravitational and other external body forces are (2)∇·V=0 and (3)∂V∂t+V·∇V=-1ρ∇p+μνρ∇2V
The half Sommerfeld model is used to apply the pressure boundary conditions. Equations (2) and (3) are solved with the CFD code that was developed in ANSYS multiphysics.

According to the grid sensitivity related to hydrodynamic solution, sixteen tests have been done. The element divisions that have been used in the circumferential direction of the bearing were 45, 90, 180 and 360, whereas the element divisions that have been used across the journal bearing oil film were 6, 8, 10 and 12. Further, the divisions that have been used in the axial direction were 6, 8, 10 and 12. The optimum combination regarding the grid needed, taking into consideration simultaneously the error and the time to get the solution, was 180 divisions in the circumferential direction, 10 divisions across the bearing’s oil film and 10 divisions in the axial direction. In Figure 2, the bearing model with the pressure contours is shown. Figure 2.

The stiffness and damping linear coefficients are defined29 as (6)Kij=∂Fi∂Xj and Cij=∂Fi∂X·j where X=x,y,X·=x·,y· and i and j denote the X- and Y-directions, respectively.

sec.title: AMB geometry and linear approximation
sec.p:
Conceptually, a typical magnetic bearing is composed of four horseshoe-shaped electromagnets. This configuration is shown in Figure 7. The four magnets are arranged evenly around a circular shaft that can be levitated, which is made from a ferromagnetic material, such as iron. Each electromagnet can only produce a force that attracts the rotor iron to it, and thus, all four electromagnets must act in concert, to produce a force of arbitrary magnitude and direction on the rotor. Figure 7.
Magnetic bearing composed of four discrete horseshoe-shaped electromagnets.
The force F for one horseshoe-shaped electromagnet,31 is (8)F=B22A2μ0cosa=μ0Nw2AI2g2cosa=kI2g2cosa where k=μ0Nw2A and μ0 is the magnetic permeability of the vacuum.

Usually, two counteracting pairs of magnets operate in a magnetic bearing. In this case, one magnet is driven with the sum of the bias and the control current (Ib + Ic), and the other magnet is driven with the difference (Ib − Ic).
For each direction, the resultant force represents the difference of forces between both magnets. In the X-axis, for example (Figure 7), the force is (9)Fx=F+-F-=k((Ib+Ic)2(g-x)2-(Ib-Ic)2(g+x)2)cosa

Equation (9) (force versus current) can be linearised by taking into account that x=g0, where g0 is the minimum bearing air gap. Thus, the linearised force is given by the expression (10)Fx(x,Ic)=(4μ0Nw2AIbg2Ic+4μ0Nw2AIb2g3x)cosα=kiIc-ksx where x represents the eccentricity of the shaft in the X-axis, and ki and ks are the linearised force/current and force/displacement at the operating point, respectively (11)ki=4μ0Nw2AIg2cosα, I={Ib,for Ic≤IbIc,for Ic>Ib and ks=-4μ0Nw2A(Ib2+Ic2)g3cosα
Using a similar approximation, the force in the direction of the Y-axis can be calculated.
The damping coefficient for one degree of freedom (DOF) can be approximated by31 (12)CAMB=-mks2ki
The linear force–current dependence fails when the current is not just the bias current, when the iron of the magnetic circuit is saturated or when the rotor is eccentric.32

An essential condition for an AMB system to work normally is to have a suitable stiffness and damping. The stiffness of AMBs can be divided into two types: position stiffness caused by the bearing structure and current stiffness caused by the controller.

sec.title: Model validation for AMB operation
sec.p:
For the 2D magnetostatics analysis, the multiphysics module of ANSYS was used for the finite element simulation. In this model, the deformation of the shaft is not taken into account. The PLANE53 element is suitable for 2D models (planar and axisymmetric) of magnetic fields. The element is defined by eight nodes and has up to four DOFs per node: the Z-component of the magnetic potential vector (AZ), the time-integrated electric scalar potential (VOLT), the electric current (CURR) and the electromotive force (EMF). Regarding the grid to obtain the solution of the electromagnetic field, the automatic (smart) sizing was selected, and the size level for the elements was set to the ‘fine’ option. A total of 5280 elements and 15,895 nodes are used (Figure 8). Figure 8.
Finite element grid of the radial magnetic bearing.

Each element has a nonlinear magnetic capability for modelling B–H curves or permanent magnet demagnetisation curves. The B–H data used are given in American Society for Metals33 for pure annealed iron. When the rotor is rotating, no magnetic flux penetrates through the solid rotor. Thus, when analysing the bearing for this operating point, the shaft is modelled as air. The geometry from Matti et al.32 is as following: rotor weight of 300 N, stator diameter of 164 mm, core length of 45 mm, rotor diameter of 93 mm, geometric air gap of 0.4 mm, magnetic air gap of 0.44 mm, 100 number of rounds per pole, teeth width of 18 mm, slot-to-slot diameter of 127 mm and thickness-to-rotor laminations of 14.35 mm. The AMB is modelled in 2D (plane-symmetry) because the axial length of the analysed bearing body is much greater than the dimensions in the cross-sectional bearing plane (Figure 9). Figure 9.
Finite element field (B) plot of radial magnetic bearing.
The Maxwell equations of the AMB are34 (13)∇×H=-JZ∇·B=0B=μH}
These equations are solved using the FEM. The magnetic potential vector Am produced is (14)∇·Am=0
From equations (13) and (14), the partial differential equation of the magnetic potential in the 2D plane field is (15)∇2Am=-μJZ
In the 2D plane magnetic field, the current density vector J and the magnetic potential vector Am have only one component, JZ and AZ, respectively, in the Z-direction.

In magnetic bearings, it is assumed that no flux penetrates outside the stator of the magnetic bearing, and thus, the magnetic vector potential at the boundary of the magnetic bearing is constant.32 Therefore, the two boundary conditions are (16)AZ=0 and (17)∂Az∂n=0 where n is the normal direction of the curved surface of the boundary.
A 2D Newton–Raphson search technique is applied to calculate the equilibrium position of the journal centre when the sum of the magnetic forces and the external loads equals zero (18)Σ(Fm+Fext)=0
A 2D Newton–Raphson method is also used to locate the journal equilibrium position from which the bearing dynamic coefficients are evaluated by means of the small perturbation technique.

In Figure 10, the bearing force versus current is presented. The results from the present simulation and the simulation in Matti et al.32 are compared with the linear approximation of equation (10). Good agreement between the linear approximation and this article results is seen. Figure 10.
Magnetic bearing force versus control current.

The deviation between the present model and the model of Matti et al.32 is due to the difference in nonlinear properties of the materials and the difference in the coil area. In the present model, the coil cross section was 159.93 × 10−6 m2, whereas in Matti et al.,32 this quantity is not explicitly mentioned. Additionally, in this 2D magnetostatic model, the shaft was modelled as air to be considered as a rotating shaft, and furthermore no magnetic flux can penetrate through the solid iron.32

The stiffness and damping coefficients are essential to study the response of a rotor on AMBs and its stability. In Figures 11 and 12, the current stiffness ki and position stiffness ks of an active hydromagnetic bearing are presented. The linear approximation of equation (11) is compared with the finite element solution of this study and those of Matti et al.32 The deviation of the linear approximation and FEM solutions becomes grater, when the current increases, because of the saturation of the magnetic field in the materials of the electromagnets, whereas between the FEM solutions, the deviation is due to the small variations of the B–H properties of the materials that are used.33 Figure 11.
Current stiffness coefficient versus control current.
Figure 12.
Position stiffness coefficient versus control current.

sec.title: AHJB geometry
sec.p:
A specific design is proposed here, a hydromagnetic (hydrodynamic and electromagnetic) bearing that works under a common shell. The basic idea is a bearing design that can operate as a hydrodynamic bearing, an AMB and as a hydromagnetic bearing (Sommerfeld number corresponding to a proper eccentricity e and attitude angle ϕ). The magnetic bearing could be imposed on the hydrodynamic bearing, thus:
giving the possibility of sharing the load to increase the bearing load-carrying capacity for the same e and ϕ. Suppose that a hydrodynamic equilibrium is achieved. Then, a small increase of the external load with simultaneous controlled (due to controller) increment of the magnetic field is expected to maintain the shaft at the same equilibrium point, offering thus higher load capacity (for every equilibrium point (e, ϕ): Fm + Fh = Fext). According to the above operation principle, the load-carrying capacity of the HB can be increased, and
giving the possibility of increasing the stability threshold, by imposing the magnetic bearing on the hydrodynamic one.

The AHJB consists of the following primary items (Figure 13). The common outer shell (1), the horseshoe-shaped electromagnets (2), the coils (3), the inner ring (4) and the oil inlet (5). Figure 13.
Basic geometry of the AHJB.
AHJB: active hydromagnetic journal bearing.

An inner ring is used so the bearing can work as a hydrodynamic bearing. The inner face of the ring and the external diameter of the rotor have a suitable diameter ratio, where the hydrodynamic field can be developed properly. The inner ring could be made by a non-magnetic material which would not influence the electromagnetic field.

The stator, from which the horseshoe-shaped electromagnets are made, consists of many thin iron slices with soft magnetic properties, to reduce the eddy currents when AC current is used to power the coil. If DC current is used to power the coil, the stator is constructed from a compact material. The air gap between the electromagnets and rotor has to be greater than the hydrodynamic clearance to fit the recommended size. Moreover, an outer shell (item 1 of Figure 13) is used, which encloses the entire bearing setup. Finally, two sensors (item 6 of Figure 14) perpendicular to each other should be installed to measure the position of the rotor. Figure 14.
Completed AHJB with rotor and sensors.
AHJB: active hydromagnetic journal bearing.

In a journal bearing, an eccentricity e exists between the centre of the bearing Ob and the centre of the journal Oj. Thus, the oil film thickness h, is between h0 (minimum film thickness) and hmax (maximum film thickness), and operates in the hydrodynamic region. The geometrical characteristics of the AHJB are shown in Figure 15. Figure 15.
Journal bearing with magnets at radius Rm.

sec.title: AHJB geometrical and operational restrictions
sec.p:
In this paragraph, the geometrical and operational limitations of the AHJB are presented. A case study is explicitly written to clarify all of the limitations in terms of the radial clearance, air gap and its combinations to obtain the hybrid operation regimes of the two bearing components. In this study, where the main target is the hybrid journal bearing, the hydrodynamic part of the design has been developed based on Sommerfeld number. However, other design methods, like this of Hirani et al.,35 could also be used for a rapid performance evaluation of the hydrodynamic part of the journal bearing used.Case study
Α bearing with radius Rb = 0.04007 m, LD=0.5 and a radial clearance c = 70E − 6 m, is considered, that has absolute oil viscosity μv = 0.02 Pa·s. The Sommerfeld number is defined as (19)S=μvNsP(Rjc)2
Assuming that the bearing rotates at N = 3000 r/min or Ns = 50 r/s, then, the load capacity of the hydrodynamic component of the bearing is represented as (20)F=μvNsLDS(Rjc)2
Regarding the magnetic bearing component of the proposed AHJB, the following characteristics are considered: permeability of the vacuum (μ0) = 4π10−7N/A2, number of horseshoe-shaped electromagnetic poles = 4, width of each electromagnetic pole = 20 mm, cross-sectional area of each electromagnetic leg = 2.66E − 04 m2, coil diameter = 1 mm, windings of the coil per pole = 330, air gap size = 0.3 mm, slot-to-slot diameter = 160 mm and external bearing diameter = 200 mm.
Thus, the above design formulas (8), (9), (10), (19) and (20) can be applied to these parameters to predict the bearing’s performance. Specifically, equations (8) and (20) are used to obtain the required current and load capacity for either the magnetic operation or the hydrodynamic operation of the bearing respectively, with respect to a common range of Sommerfeld numbers. As for the magnetic operation, the saturation of the materials of the shaft and the stator is taken into account. In Figure 16, the bearing force of the specific HB is determined for the Sommerfeld number that corresponds to its hydrodynamic operational parameters. From the same nomogram, the required current can also be determined for the magnetic bearing, to obtain the same force as the hydrodynamic bearing, using bias current of 0.5 A. Figure 16.
Sommerfeld number versus bearing force and control current.
Figure 17.
Magnet distance g over radial clearance c versus Sommerfeld number, for LD=1.
Regarding the HB operation, a common area between the air gap (magnetic bearings) and radial clearances (journal bearings) must be defined. Below, the relevant analysis is presented.
The radial clearance of the hydrodynamic component is defined as c = Rb − Rj and can be in the following region (21)500≤Rbc≤1000 and c, h0 and hmax are related in the following manner (22)h0+hmax=2c or hmax=2c-h0
Regarding the magnetic bearings, the equilibrium point typically is the centre of the bearing. However, the magnetic bearings can operate eccentrically in certain limits, defined by the air gap in each application. In the proposed hydromagnetic bearing, the equilibrium position is considered to be eccentric, as it is defined in Farmakopoulos et al.25
According to the hybrid journal bearing patent,27 the gap (g0) between the magnet and the rotating shaft should lie in the region (23)g1≤g0≤g2 where g1 = 300 µm and g2 = 500 µm. Because there is eccentricity, g0 and gmax, from equation (23) must both satisfy the following inequalities (24)g1≤g0 and gmax≤g2
To force the HB to operate in both regions, the magnets are placed not at the journal radius (Rb) but at a larger radius Rm (Figure 15), where (25)Rm=Rb+g
Thus, the magnets are placed at a distance g from the inner surface of the bearing. If one adds the minimum film thickness h0, the total distance of the magnet from the rotor g0 can be taken as (Figure 15) (26)g0=g+h0 and equation (24) becomes due to (26), g1≤g0 or g1≤g+h0 that is equivalent to g1-h0≤g resulting in (27)g1c-(h0c)≤gc and gmax≤g2 or hmax+g≤g2 equals to 2c-h0+g≤g2 or 2-(h0c)+gc≤g2c resulting in (28)gc≤g2c-2+(h0c)
The minimum film thickness h0c can be obtained from the Raymondi and Boyd diagram as a function of the Sommerfeld number.
From equations (27) and (28), the magnet dimensionless distance gc should lie inside the defined region. In Figure 17, the ratio gc is plotted against the Sommerfeld number.
Thus, if the radial clearance is c = 100 µm and the Sommerfeld number is S = 0.1, then from Figure 17, the following inequality can be obtained (29)2.5≤gc≤3.5 or (30)250μm≤g≤350μm
After selecting a particular radial clearance c for any Sommerfeld number, the specific distance g can be obtained. The Sommerfeld number S and the g/c are quantities inversely proportional.
To conclude, the concept of the hydromagnetic design, as it is introduced here, can be realised, being the result of the achievable combination of the hydrodynamic and magnetic bearing characteristics.

sec.title: AHJB modes of operation
sec.p: Suppose that the external load of the bearing is Fext and is supported by the HB. Suppose that Fm is the part of the external load that the magnetic bearing supports with the aid of the magnetic field, and suppose that Fh is the part of the external load that is supported by the hydrodynamic oil pressure field. Assuming small vibrations around the equilibrium point, if one defines λ=[0,1],λ∈R, which is the part of the external load that the magnetic field supports, then three cases could be reported. The first case is (31a)Fm=0, Fh=Fext, λ=0 the second case is (31b)Fm=Fext, Fh=0, λ=1 and the third case is (31c)Fm=λFext, Fh=(1-λ)Fext, 0<λ<1

In the first and second case, the entire external load is supported by the hydrodynamic or magnetic field, respectively. In the third case, the external load is divided into two parts, λFext and (1 − λ)Fext, which are simultaneously supported by the magnetic and the hydrodynamic field, respectively. Note that in every case Fm+Fh=Fext.

A HB is considered with LD=0.5, oil viscosity μv = 0.012 Pa·s and oil density ρ = 960 kg/m3 with a radius shaft Rj = 46.5 mm, as in Figure 15, and radial clearance c = 70 µm, as in Figure 18. Figure 18.
Active hydromagnetic journal bearing definitions.

The HB has eight poles, each with coil cross-sectional area 129 mm2 and a bias current of 2 A. The magnetic air gap is g = 0.44 mm, so during the bearing’s operation, the minimum magnetic air gap can be g-c=0.44-0.07=0.37mm and the maximum g+c=0.44+0.07=0.51mm, values which are suitable for a controller to control the rotor’s position, the number of rounds per pole is 100, the width of the teeth is 18 mm, the slot-to-slot diameter is 127 mm, the external bearing diameter is 164 mm and the ring’s thickness is 5 mm. The shaft rotates at 50 r/s and the external load is supposed to be Fext = 1500 N.
Three hybrid operation modes of the bearing can be distinguished.

sec.title: Constant external load
sec.p:
Initially, the entire load is supported by the hydrodynamic function of the bearing. The Sommerfeld number can be evaluated as S=(μνNsP)(Rjc)2. An equilibrium point (e, ϕ) = (ex, ey) of the journal corresponds to this number. Then, gradually, the hydrodynamically supported load is decreased, and the magnetically supported load is increased in such a way that the sum remains constant and equal to Fext (Figure 27) which would result in a new equilibrium position of the journal. The locus of the equilibrium positions of the hydrodynamic function of the journal is shown in Figure 28. In this way, the bearing operation can pass from the hydrodynamic oil field to the magnetic field, and gradually, the centres of both the journal and bearing will coincide. Figure 19.

Figure 20.

The hydrodynamic stiffness and damping coefficients are shown in Figures 19 and 20, respectively, and the dimensionless hydrodynamic stiffness coefficients and the dimensionless hydrodynamic damping coefficients are shown in Figures 21 and 22, respectively. The Sommerfeld number versus the λ is shown in Figure 23. As for the magnetic characteristics, the control current in the Y-direction and in the X-direction versus λ are shown in Figures 24 and 25, respectively. The magnetic damping coefficients for one DOF versus λ are shown in Figure 26. Figure 26.

The hybrid current stiffness coefficients are shown in Figure 29, which are the magnetic current stiffness coefficients, because the hydrodynamic bearing does not have these types of coefficients. The hybrid position stiffness coefficients are obtained from the result of the sum of the hydrodynamic and the electromagnetic position stiffness coefficients (Figure 30). In Figure 31, the hybrid damping coefficients without coupling terms are presented. Figure 29.

sec.title: Constant equilibrium point
sec.p: When the hydrodynamic part of the bearing supports an external load Fext with a Sommerfeld number S, there is an equilibrium point at (e, ϕ). Then, the function of the magnetic bearing is introduced when the control current of the electromagnet is gradually increased while simultaneously increasing the external load and maintaining a constant equilibrium point. If the hydrodynamic part supports 1500 N, then the Sommerfeld number is S = 0.7 and the equilibrium point is (ɛ, ϕ) = (0.4, 64.7°). Then, the electromagnet with a bias current Ib = 2 A, a control current in the Y-direction of Iy = 4.071 A, and a control current in the X-direction of Ix = −0.134 A, adds an additional load-carrying capacity of 1500 N, and thus, the total force acting from the bearing is 3000 N, where the equilibrium position of the shaft, is maintained. Moreover, the stiffness and damping coefficients are summed, which ensures the safety and stability of the rotating shaft.

sec.title: Increasing stability
sec.p: Maintaining a constant external load (Fext = 1500 N) and shaft position, the current of the magnet is increased to alter the magnetic stiffness and overcome a type of instability.24 The purpose is to alter the stiffness and damping coefficients of the bearing to avoid undesirable effects in the instability regions. As a result, when the bearing works as a hydrodynamic bearing, the magnetic part can apply the appropriate currents, to retain the shaft without the magnetic part carrying any load so that the journal bearing is not unloaded; an unloaded journal bearing is significantly less stable than a loaded journal bearing. Therefore, the magnetic part operates as a control system. Then, the stiffness and damping coefficients are summed, which results in the safety and stability of the rotating shaft.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, a new HB design is introduced. The AHJB is designed, and its hybrid operation as a hydrodynamic and AMB is presented. The operation of the hybrid journal bearing is more sophisticated than each of the two bearing types.

The magnets are proposed to be placed within a larger diameter than those of the internal surface of the inner bearing ring, and can be activated in every eccentricity and all attitude angles in which the hydrodynamic bearing operates. This position is mechanically regulated and depends on the hydrodynamic bearing configuration (Figures 15 to 18). Both AHJB configurations (magnetic and hydrodynamic) operate in a common outer shell. The equilibrium points of the hydrodynamic journal bearing lie at the well-known locus. Furthermore, the equilibrium points of the shaft centre moving inside the magnetic bearing shall follow the same locus (does not coincide with the bearing centre), and thus, the hydrodynamic operation is not disturbed.

A finite element model was developed and introduced into ANSYS software, to calculate the hydrodynamic operation, and a nonlinear finite element model was used to calculate the magnetic forces as functions of the control current, using the same software package. In addition, the dynamic stiffness and damping coefficients of the new AHJB are presented in this study. The hydromagnetic bearing exploits the advantages of both of its components at low and high speeds. Moreover, the safety during the operation is increased because if one of the bearing components becomes faulty, the HB can continue its function using the other component.

In addition, there is a possibility of controlling, the position of the shaft (the controller design is beyond the scope of this article), through the appropriate controller of the magnetic or of the hybrid operation of the bearing (equation (31c), e.g. λ = 0.5).

Three operational scenarios have been presented where the hybrid function is described in details, where the load-carrying capacity is increased (Figure 27) and the stiffness and damping coefficients (Figures 29 to 31) are varied at the same equilibrium position (Figure 28), which subsequently allow control possibilities and an increase in the lifetime of the bearing.
